channel.title: [POLL] Top Produced Genres
channel.description:
Hey dudes. Just curious to hear what genres you guys like to produce, if I’ve missed any just let me know and I’ll fix it up.
(Note this isn’t about what genre you listen to- it’s about what you have produced and released)
[poll type=multiple min=1 max=20 public=true] * House * Deep House * Progressive house * Tropical House * Futurebass * Electro House * Melbourne Bounce * Bigroom House * DnB * Dubstep * Ambient * Chill * Lo-Fi * Trance * Synthwave * Trap * Minimal * Vaporwave * Electro Swing * Other [/poll]

item.title: [POLL] Top Produced Genres
item.dc:creator: Alyen
item.description:
akabillposters:

Does that stop ‘pop’ being a Genre?

Pop would be another, what I would call, “Phantom genre”.

When those who speak of their love for EDM, how is that making or showing it as a genre?

Personal opinion aside, given that the term EDM is used a lot in promos and events, we can assume that most people exposed to this term may associate the following music as EDM(as it is). The lack of awareness of the many(or a few) genres and sub-genres within EDM, those people will likely call the genre of whatever music EDM. This will eventually make EDM into a recognizable genre(as it might be today). But EDM isn’t practically a genre. It has no true sub-genres. If EDM fathers House(making house a sub-genre of edm), then what do you call the children of House… sub-sub-genres?
To end, perhaps all genres were coined by no particular one person, but there is a logic to them.
Oh, to answer your questions from your first post:
Q: Is Pop a genre?
A: No, it’s a term tagged to music that is currently popular. Future Bass would be Pop music currently in this community.
Q: Is electronic a genre?
A: Yes, it’s a “default” genre for those who tracks don’t fit in any genres or do not know what genre their tracks belong in.
Q: Is EDM a subset of Electronic, Dance Music, or both (or neither)?
A: No, EDM isn’t subset or sub-genre of EDM.

Good talk.

Read full topic

item.title: [POLL] Top Produced Genres
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
Alyen:

Very well said. Let say EDM as a genre, what does it add to the already existing pile of genres? I could see EDM working well with “consumers” who are look for dance music in particular. But EDM blankets a large amount of digitally created music, which is the issue for me.
Let’s say you’re out partying and you hear a track that makes you want to create music like that. The track genre would be Jackin’ House, but the artist labeled it as EDM. So as you try to collect more reference material to better understand EDM, you quickly realize that all other EDM sound different than your target track

The exact same argument could be made for ‘electronic’, ‘jazz’, ‘rock’, ‘pop’. Each of them are genres far more encompassing than the term EDM. Does that prevent them from being ‘genres’? I think you’d struggle to assert that it does. So, if we can accept that genre can be any distinction within music, from the ‘primary’ genres (e.g. rock, classical, pop, electronic, …) to the most granular, how is EDM, that sits somewhere in between, any different?

 

the artist labeled it as EDM

How many artists do you know tag their stuff simply as ‘electronic’ or simply ‘house’. The tendency, especially amongst music marketing, is generally towards specificity - generally in service of highly targeted, highly tribal, groups.
More descriptiveness allows those who wish to to hone in more quickly on the narrowest of distinctions.

However, just because ‘EDM’ is not the ‘most specific’ label that can be attached, it doesn’t stop ‘EDM’ being one of the labels that can be attached – no more than it stops ‘house’ being a genre.

Example:

Ask Chvrches, or any of their most dedicated fans what genre they are, there’s a good chance they’ll say ‘electro-pop’. Many Chvrches listeners would probably reject being calling it simply ‘pop’.
If you asked a ‘pop’ fan if they liked Chvrches, a great many of them would say yes, because for them, they do fall within that genre.

Does that stop ‘pop’ being a Genre?

(fwiw, iTunes labels them ‘alternative’. Oddly, imo, Pitchfork refers to them as Pop/R&B.)

 

As for EDM… soulless and useless.

…in your opinion. Some will talk about their love of “EDM” with enthusiasm and excitement, because it refers to music that they find exciting and enjoyable.

 
(None of this mentions the fact that EDM is, in some growing quarters, coming to refer more specifically to the high-energy, positive vibe music of house rhythm-oriented producers such as deadmau5, Garrix, Steve Aoki and big room DJs-turned-producers.)

 
Just to clarify, I’m saying that neither of us are entirely correct. In practice, things are always much muddier.

I’m not saying that EDM should replace the many, MANY sub-genres or be the only genre label used by music of a certain characteristic. Just that it has an established position and a useful role as a label used to identify music of certain shared characteristics — and that’s all that music genres are.

To my mind, to deny that is to deny the meaning of the word genre. And I don’t see why that’s a battle some are so keen to fight.

 
I’ll end on a quote from Chvrches…

there is grey between the lines

 
I’m done now.

Read full topic

item.title: [POLL] Top Produced Genres
item.dc:creator: Alyen
item.description:
@akabillposters
Very well said. Let say EDM as a genre, what does it add to the already existing pile of genres? I could see EDM working well with “consumers” who are look for dance music in particular. But EDM blankets a large amount of digitally created music, which is the issue for me.
Let’s say you’re out partying and you hear a track that makes you want to create music like that. The track genre would be Jackin’ House, but the artist labeled it as EDM. So as you try to collect more reference material to better understand EDM, you quickly realize that all other EDM sound different than your target track. Same goes for die hard fans of particular styles, if artists start labeling dance music EDM, those fans will have a hard time finding the style they loved.

I understand what you’re saying but EDM has no place in being a genre… anything that could be tagged as EDM, most likely already have a proper name, which only creates confusion. The confusion can be seen when you see someone stating things like, “Trap vs EDM” or “I hate EDM, House is better”… when both (Trap, House) are EDM.
After clicking on both your link, I’ve still haven’t seen EDM used as a genre professionally or not even in those links. The difference in names of genres being umbrella terms and EDM being an umbrella term, is that
EDM: dance music
Techno: Dark, robotic, hard sounds.
House: Groove, funk.
Trance: Hypnotic, melodic.

As you can tell, the proper names add way more dimensions to describe the music before it even hits your ears… As for EDM… soulless and useless.

Read full topic

item.title: [POLL] Top Produced Genres
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
Alyen:

From my understanding EDM is an umbrella term for music made with electronics(digitally) that you can dance to(anything that could be played in a club or party setting).

Why couldn’t that serve as the basis for something called a ‘genre’?
After all, what is a ‘genre’ if not simply an umbrella term used to group together things that share certain characteristics?

It seems to me that there are no hard and fast rules that dictate what constitutes a definition for a genre.
Some are technology-based, and more ‘outcome’-agnostic – e.g. Electronic. Some are more ‘outcome’-oriented, and more technology-agnostic – e.g. Pop

A good example might be Depeche Mode.
In the UK, they’re probably considered part of ‘Electronic Pop’/Synth-Pop. In the US, they seem to be considered part of Rock (though the US does seem to use the term Rock more loosely than others, so…).

For me, it isn’t a case of clear lineages. EDM, imo, is both a descendant of ‘electronic music’ and ‘dance music’ (‘dance’ music, at least as use by most below the age of 50, has been somewhat subsumed ‘spiritually’ (albeit silently) into electronic, due to the weight of how much dance music is produced in recent decades.)

As someone who lived (and danced) through the early days of house and techno, it’s muddy, even to me.

 

EDM… I’ve never seen it used as a genre

I’ve seen it used many times exactly in the same way you’d use a ‘genre’…

e.g.
https://soundcloud.com/tags/edm
Spotify also appears to treat it like a genre…
 

The term EDM hasn’t went through such a process to be recognized as a genre, since it’s haven’t been claimed as a sub-genre by any professional

There is no ‘Council of Music Elders’ who decide these things. They occur far more organically through a mixture of thoughts from vested listeners, such as makers, fans, journalists, etc…

I suspect that, despite whatever a decreasing number of ‘producers’ say or believe, EDM we’ll increasingly see EDM used as a genre. Defending the purist view is, imo, both pointless (because it’s defending a distinction without a difference) and also futile, because fewer and fewer people influencing these things are actually producers who care about a purist view of the term – and because it’s a useful descriptor and because there’s no down-side to it being used used as a genre.

 
I think, bottom line, it comes down to the question I asked at the start of this post…

What is a ‘genre’ if not simply an umbrella term used to categorise things that share certain characteristics?

 
Anyhoo…

Read full topic

item.title: [POLL] Top Produced Genres
item.dc:creator: Alyen
item.description:
@akabillposters
What would be the characteristics of a EDM genre track and if it’s a sub-genre where does it evolve from, in your view? From my understanding EDM is an umbrella term for music made with electronics(digitally) that you can dance to(anything that could be played in a club or party setting). Electronic/Electronica is a genre used to describe music that doesn’t fit in any other established genre. At some point, the genre House contained Techno and Trance as sub-genres… eventually they both grew big enough to be considered by (those who care to name styles) as its own genre with many sub-genres. The term EDM hasn’t went through such a process to be recognized as a genre, since it’s haven’t been claimed as a sub-genre by any professional(to my knowledge). So labeling the genre of danceable music as EDM, make as much sense as labeling music that contains a guitar “guitar music”.
I’m not sure of the history of the term EDM, but I’ve never seen it used as a genre. I only see it being used as a genre by non-producers. Then again, it’s hard enough to find any information thoroughly explaining genres(&sub) difference and how to properly identify them.

Read full topic

item.title: [POLL] Top Produced Genres
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
Alyen:

EDM isn’t a genre

I don’t get why is “isn’t”.

Is ‘Pop’ a genre? If not, what is it?
Is ‘Electronic’ a genre? If not, what is it?

Is EDM a subset of Electronic, Dance Music, or both (or neither)?

If ‘electronic’ is a genre (which I currently consider/understand it to be) and (e.g.) DubStep is a (sub-)genre, then the one in between - ‘EDM’ - must surely be a genre/sub-genre too, no?
People often refer to (e.g.) FB, DubStep, Big Room, Hardstyle, etc… as direct/indirect genres/sub-genres within EDM, so why wouldn’t EDM be considered as a genre/sub-genre?
( I wouldn’t classify any of those as direct, first-generation offspring of ‘Electronic’.)

To me, it’s like saying that Jazz isn’t a genre because bebop, hard jazz, free jazz, smooth jazz, swing, ragtime, nu jazz, etc… all exist.
Or saying that House isn’t a genre because of the many sub-forms of House that exist.

 
I know there are some genre purists who would argue the toss between genre and sub-genre, but I can’t think of a reason or situation where it doesn’t make sense to consider EDM as a genre (or sub-genre) of some type.

Happy to have someone explain to me why I’m wrong.

Read full topic
